form.definition: noun V or v is the twenty-second letter of the English alphabet.
abbreviation for versus.
noun A vacancy is a job that is available at a place of work. The factory has a vacancy for a skilled fitter. I am afraid there are no vacancies in the sales department at the moment.
noun A vacancy in a hotel or guest house is a room which is available to be occupied. NO VACANCIES The only vacancy we have is a room on the second floor.
adjective If something is vacant, it is not being used. Is this seat vacant? When you lock the toilet, the sign outside changes from VACANT to ENGAGED. None of the phone boxes was vacant.
adjective If a job or position is vacant, nobody has been appointed to it. The position of marketing manager is vacant at the moment.
adjective If a house or unit, or a room in a hotel is vacant, nobody is living or staying there. The house is vacant at the moment but tenants will be moving in next week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vacate Guests should vacate the room by noon on the day of departure.

form.definition: noun A vacation is a holiday. I'm planning to take a vacation in Bali. I don't want to think about that nowI'm on vacation.
noun A vacation is a part of the year when schools and colleges are closed. I took a Christmas job during the summer vacation.
noun A vaccine is a substance which is made from the germs of a particular disease. It is injected into people in small doses to prevent them from getting the disease.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb vaccinate Have you been vaccinated against polio?noun vaccination I need to get some vaccinations before my trip.

form.definition: noun A vacuum is an empty space which contains no air or other gas.
noun A vacuum or vacuum cleaner is an electrical ~appliance which sucks up dust and dirt from floors and carpets.
verb If you vacuum the floor or carpet, you clean it by using a vacuum cleaner. I just want to vacuum the lounge room before the guests arrive. If there's one chore I really hate, it's vacuuming.

dictionary.entry: vaginav@`dZa:In@ noun A woman's vagina is the passage that leads from the outside of her body to the uterus. In sexual intercourse the man puts his penis into the woman's vagina. ... WORD FAMILY adjective vaginal

form.definition: adjective If something is vague, it is not very clear or definite. We could see only vague shapes in the fog. The details of the trip are still fairly vague.

adjective If someone is vague, they do not have things clearly fixed in their mind. Meng couldn't get any sense out of the womanshe was quite vague. He's hopelessly vaguehis wife has to organise everything for him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb vaguely The man seemed vaguely familiar. It tastes vaguely of onion.noun vagueness

form.definition: adjective If someone is vain, they are very proud of their own appearance, intelligence or ability. Celine's the vainest girl I've ever metshe spends hours admiring herself in the mirror.
in vain In formal language, if you say something is in vain, you mean it is not successful. All our efforts to cheer him up were in vain. They battled in vain to extinguish the blaze.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See vanity.

form.definition: adjective If something such as a ticket is valid, it is officially in order. The passport is not validit expired last month. This offer is valid for the next three months.
adjective If something such as an argument or conclusion is valid, it is based on sound reasoning. They have no valid objection to the proposal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun validity

form.definition: noun A valley is a piece of low land between two hills or mountains.
adjective If something is valuable, it is worth a lot of money. She owns a lot of valuable jewellery.

adjective If something such as help or advice is valuable, it is useful. Thank you for your valuable help. I found her comments on my work very valuable. The course gave me valuable practical experience.
valuables Valuables are expensive items that you own, such as antiques and jewellery. Be sure that your valuables are adequately insured.

dictionary.entry:
value`vAlju:valuesvaluedvaluing 1a noun The value of something is what it is worth. This house has risen in value since we bought
b noun The value of something is its usefulness or importance. There's no value in repeating what we've already done. I set a high value on loyalty. 2a verb If someone values something, they estimate what it is worth. I asked the jeweller to value my watch for the insurance.
verb If you value something, it is important to you. I really value my friendship with Lee. If you've got a moment, I'd value your advice on what to do. It was only after he left that I realised how much I'd valued him.
good value If something is good value, it is a bargain. It is well worth what it costs. This wine is really good value at $10. You usually get better value by buying the larger size. I've certainly got good value out of this coatI've worn it every day this winter.
values Your values are your moral principles and your beliefs about what is important in society. It seemed to her that the younger generation had no values.
... WORD FAMILY valuable See noun valuation adjective valueless noun valuer

form.definition: noun A valve is a device which opens and shuts to control the flow of a liquid or gas. One of the valves in his heart had become blocked.
noun A van is a fairly small vehicle used for carrying goods.

noun A vandal is someone who deliberately destroys or damages other people's property. The windows of the disused factory were broken by vandals. Some vandals cut my grandmother's garden hose in half.~ ... WORD FAMILY verb vandalise (<or> vandalize) The shed had been vandalised.noun vandalism
noun Vanilla is a food flavouring. It can be extracted from the pod of a tropical plant, or created artificially.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective vanilla ...vanilla ice-cream. ...vanilla essence.

form.definition: verb If something vanishes, it disappears. It is no longer visible. The ship vanished over the horizon. Rub the lotion into your skin until it vanishes. My scissors were here a minute ago, but now they've vanished!
noun Vanity is the quality of being vain, or too proud of your appearance, intelligence or ability. The defeat was a blow to his vanity.
noun Vapour is made up of tiny particles of liquid in the air, such as steam, mist or fog.
noun Variety is things being different from each other. The shop has a large variety of clothes. I'd like a job with more variety.
noun A variety of something is a particular kind or sort. Which variety of beer is itFosters, VB or Tooheys?

adjective If things are described as various, there are several different ones. Often you use this word to refer to a number of things in a vague way, without giving details. I've still got various matters to sort out. There were various pieces of equipment in the room. I asked various colleagues, but nobody knew anything about it.

many and various If you say things are many and various, you mean that there are a lot of different ones. Note that various is not used after the noun it describes except in this phrase. John's got some flaws, but his good points are many and various.
noun Varnish is a clear liquid which is used as a finish on wood or woodwork to give a hard shiny surface when it dries.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb varnish

form.definition: verb If something varies, it is different at different times. If things vary, there are differences between them. The temperature never varies very much. Her moods vary a lot. ~ Prices varyit's worth shopping around.
verb If you vary something, you change it. I decided to vary my routine and walk to work. You can vary this dish by using different vegetables.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See variety.adjective See various.adjective variable The weather has been very variable this week.noun variation He sticks to the same routine without variation.

form.definition: noun A vase is a container used to hold and display flowers. Vases are usually made of china or glass.

adjective If something is vast, it is very large indeed. It is huge or enormous. Australia is a vast continent. There is a vast difference between the two brothersone so generous and the other totally selfish. She makes a vast amount of money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb vastly This one is vastly superior. It would be vastly preferable to wait.

form.definition: noun A vat is a large container like a barrel used for storing liquids such as beer and whisky.
noun A VCR is a video cassette recorder.
form.note: ... SEE video.

form.definition: noun A VDU is the screen of a computer where the information is displayed.
form.note: ... NOTE This is an abbreviation from the words visual display unit.

form.definition: noun Veal is meat from a calf.
noun A vegan is someone who doesn't eat or use any products that come from animals.

noun A vegetable is a plant or part of a plant which you eat as part of a savoury dish. Potatoes, carrots, peas, beans, cabbage, broccoli and pumpkin are a few of the most common vegetables that people eat in Australia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective vegetable ...vegetable soup. ...vegetable bake.

form.definition: noun A vegetarian is someone who doesn't eat meat. Some vegetarians also don't eat fish or any products that come from animals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective vegetarian ...a vegetarian diet. ...a vegetarian restaurant. ...a vegetarian cookbook.

form.definition: noun Vegetation refers to plants in general. The bushfires destroyed most of the vegetation in the area.

dictionary.entry: vegie`vEdZi: <noun> Vegie is an informal word for vegetable.

form.definition: adjective If someone is vehement about something, they express very strong feelings about it. Luke was vehement in his opposition to the plan. The proposal encountered vehement resistance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vehemence They were surprised by the vehemence of the protests.adverb vehemently He argued vehemently in favour of keeping the factory open.

form.definition: noun A vehicle is a form of transport, especially one that travels on the road such as a car, van or bus. He swerved to avoid an oncoming vehicle. A dozen vehicles were involved in the smash. The class of driver's licence you have shows what types of vehicles you are allowed to drive.
noun A veil is a piece of cloth which women sometimes wear to cover their face and head.
verb If you veil something, you hide or disguise it. We put up wall hangings to veil the damp patches in the plaster. The report contained thinly veiled criticisms of the previous management.

noun A vein is a blood vessel that carries blood from some part of your body back to your heart so that it can receive more oxygen. A blood vessel that carries blood from your heart out to some part of your body is called an artery.
noun The thin lines on a leaf which carry sap are also called veins.
noun Velvet is a fabric which has a short thick smooth pile like a carpet, so that it feels very rich to the touch. It can be made of cotton, nylon or silk thread.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective velvety The leaf was covered in velvety down. The mousse has a velvety consistency.

form.definition: noun If a piece of furniture is made of veneer, it has a thin layer of fine wood glued onto the outside of cheap wood or chipboard.

noun A veneer is a thin layer or coating on something. The veneer is chipping off the kitchen units. Beneath his veneer of good manners he has a violent temper.~ ... WORD FAMILY verb veneer The cabinet is veneered with oak.
noun A venereal disease is a disease which is passed from one person to another by sexual intercourse, for example AIDS, syphilis and gonorrhoea.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is sexually transmitted disease or STD.

form.definition: noun In formal language, vengeance is another word for revenge.

2 with a vengeance If you do something with a vengeance, you do it with great energy and often much more than was expected or necessary. After his wife died he threw himself into his work with a vengeance. At first it was just a shower, but soon it began to rain with a vengeance.
noun The venom of a snake or spider is the poison that they inject into you if they bite or sting you. An antidote to the venom of the taipan was developed in 1955.
noun Venom is intense bitterness of feeling. She spoke of his betrayal with venom.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective venomous Australia's most venomous spiders are the redback and the funnelweb.

form.definition: verb If you ventilate a room, you bring in fresh air, usually by opening a window.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun ventilation The room is very stuffy because of poor ventilation.

form.definition: noun A venture is an undertaking in which you can't be sure of the outcome and there is a certain amount of risk involved. Andrea is trying to raise capital for a new business venture. Moving to Australia was quite a venture, but I've never regretted it.

verb If you venture somewhere, you go there even though you aren't quite sure what to expect, for example because you haven't been there before. I was pleasantly surprised when at last I ventured into town.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you venture to do something, you mean that you do it although you aren't sure what the reaction will be. I was so overawed by the company that it was a while before I ventured to speak. Might I venture to suggest you do it this way? I hardly dared to venture an opinion.
noun The venue for a public event is the place where it is held. The town is short of venues for rock concerts. They are building a major new sporting venue on the former factory site.

noun A veranda is an area joining onto the outside of a house, with a roof over it but usually without walls. Verandas are usually on the ground floor of a house. It was so hot we all slept on the veranda last night.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is verandah. ... SEE THE PICTURE at house. ... A SIMILAR WORD is balcony.

form.definition: noun In grammar, a verb is a word that refers to an action as opposed to a thing. It describes what happens or what somebody does.
adjective Verbal means relating to words or language. Sam's verbal skills are improving.
adjective Sometimes verbal refers to spoken rather than written language. I've only had a verbal answer to my letter.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is oral.

form.definition: adjective In grammar, verbal means relating to verbs. ...a verbal noun. ...a verbal use of the word.
noun A verdict in a court of law is the decision of the jury on whether a person accused of a crime is guilty or not guilty. The jury brought in a verdict of guilty.

noun A verdict can also be a judgment or decision that is made in any circumstances. Well, I'll tell you my verdictI think he shouldn't have walked out in the first place. What's the verdict? Should I add more pepper? I'm waiting for the examiner's verdict.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you verify something, you mean that you confirm that it is true. I've heard the rumours but I've been unable to verify them. Can you verify that Alex will be a trustworthy tenant? This just verifies what I've been saying all along.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun verification

form.definition: adjective If you are versatile, you are able to do lots of different things because you are adaptable and have a range of skills. These days workers have to be versatile as technology changes so rapidly. She is an amazingly versatile artist, working in three dimensions as well as oils and watercolours.

adjective If something such as ~a machine or piece of equipment is versatile, it can be used in many different ways or for different purposes. This ladder is very versatileit can be extended to various lengths or folded into a step ladder.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun versatility

form.definition: noun In formal language, verse is another word for poetry.

noun In a song or poem, a verse is a group of lines forming one of the sections into which it is divided. She started to sing 'Waltzing Matilda', but forgot the words after the first verse. The soloist sang the verses, and we all joined in with the chorus.
noun A verse is also the shortest division of a holy book such as the Bible or Koran. She quoted from Luke, chapter 3, verse 5: Every mountain and hill shall be brought low.

noun A version of something is a form of it which is different in some details to other ones. One thing is transformed by some process into different versions. I've made some corrections to the first version of the report. I've seen the movie, but not the stage version of it. The witnesses all gave different versions of what had happened.
preposition Versus means 'against'. It is used mostly in talking about the two teams that play against each other in a sports match. It looks as though it'll be Australia versus Japan in the final.
form.note: ... NOTE This is often abbreviated as v or vs.

form.definition: noun Your vertebrae are the bones of your spine or backbone.
adjective If something is vertical, it runs straight up and down. ...a vertical line.
adjective If something is vertical, it is standing up straight. The wire is suspended between vertical poles. I was so tired it was all I could do to remain vertical.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is horizontal. ... WORD FAMILY adverb vertically

form.definition: adverb You use very to emphasise the adjective or adverb that follows. It's very hot today. Her unit is very small. I've very nearly finished. I don't come here very often. I enjoyed it very much indeed. He came the very next day. ~

adjective If you say something is the very one, you mean that it is the exact one. This is the very place where John proposed to me. The first book I took off the shelf was the very one I was looking for.
noun A vessel is a ship or boat. They sailed down the east coast of Australia in a small fishing vessel.
noun In formal language, a vessel is a bowl or other container. The incense was carried in two golden vessels.
blood vessel A blood vessel is an artery or vein through which blood circulates around the body. He was so angry that I thought he was going to burst a blood vessel.
noun A vet is a doctor who treats animals. This word is a shortened form of the formal term veterinary surgeon.

verb If you vet someone or something for a particular purpose, you check very carefully to make sure they are suitable and acceptable. You have to be vetted before getting a job in the security services. My mother wants to meet my new girlfriend so she can vet her. It's impossible to vet everything the kids read.

verb If someone vetoes something, they use their authority to prevent it from happening. We all wanted to put up Christmas decorations in the canteen, but the boss vetoed the idea. My mother has vetoed wet towels inside the house.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun veto (vetoes) I didn't dare to defy his veto.

form.definition: verb If something vexes you, it makes you cross, worried or puzzled. I was vexed by his refusal. It vexes me to see you so unhappy. The problem has vexed researchers for decades.

preposition Via means 'by way of'. You use it to say that you go through a place while you are travelling. He went from Sydney to Melbourne via Yass. There are daily flights to Europe via Bangkok or Singapore.
verb If something vibrates, it shakes or trembles rapidly. I could feel the washing machine vibrating. The force of the blast made the windows vibrate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vibration

form.definition: abbreviation for Victoria.
noun In rather formal language, a vice is a bad aspect of someone's character. His main vice is that he tends to be rather self-obsessed.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is virtue.b noun A vice is something bad that someone enjoys. This word is often used in a humorous way. I eat far too much chocolate, but it's my only vice.

form.definition: noun Vice consists of illegal or undesirable activities such as drug dealing, gambling, pornography and prostitution.
noun A vice is also a device that you use to hold something firmly while you are working on it. She clamped the piece of wood into a vice.

adverb If you say something and then say vice versa, you mean that what you say is also true the other way round. Agnes loathes Belinda and vice versa. She plays tennis on Mondays and netball on Tuesdaysor vice versa, I can't remember.

noun In rather formal language, if you say something is in the vicinity of something else, you mean that it is near or close by. I'm not sure exactly where the florist is, but it's in the vicinity of the post office. Excuse me, is there a phone box in the vicinity? The cost will be in the vicinity of $500.

adjective If someone or something is vicious, they are savage or cruel. Don't go into number 14they've got a vicious dog. The whole town was outraged by the vicious murder. She's got a vicious temper. The rumour is a vicious lie.
noun A victim is someone who suffers an accident or a crime. Bystanders rushed to pull the victims from the car. The victim was taken to hospital with stab wounds.
verb If someone is victimised, they are singled out to be treated badly. He claimed that he was being victimised because of his colour.

noun A victory is the winning of a contest or battle. Christine beat her husband in the tennis tournamentI bet she enjoyed that victory! 1995 marked the fiftieth anniversary of victory in the Pacific.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is defeat. ... WORD FAMILY adjective victorious[qr

form.definition: noun A video is a machine which records television programs onto tapes and plays back these and other recordings through a television set. Don't forget to set the video before you go to bed.
form.note: ... ANOTHER TERM for this is video cassette recorder or VCR.

form.definition: noun A video or video cassette is a tape containing recorded images and sound which can be played back through a television set. I don't feel like going outlet's just get a takeaway and a video.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb video Let's video the game and then we can watch it when we get home.

form.definition: noun Videotape is magnetic tape used for recording film and television pictures and sound. These days most productions are shot on videotape rather than film. They showed a videotape of the incident.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb videotape Did you videotape the Sunday night movie?

form.definition: noun Vietnamese is the standard language spoken in Vietnam.
adjective If someone or something comes from Vietnam, you describe them as Vietnamese.

noun A view is whatever you can see from a particular place, for instance from the top of a hill, or out of a window. The unit has marvellous views of the city. The electricity cables spoil the view. The boat disappeared from view.
2a noun Your view on a subject is your opinion about it. We must take everyone's view into consideration. My view is that it's too expensive.
verb If you view something in a certain way, you have that opinion about it. As I view things, the first option is the best. I view the prospect of relocating with some dismay.

in view of You use in view of to give the circumstances which explain why something happens. In view of the fact that he made a full apology, Anna decided to forgive him. We decided to postpone the picnic in view of the bad weather.
noun A viewer is someone who watches a television program. Several viewers com~plained about the violence. The show attracted over 400 000 viewers.

adjective If someone or something is vigorous, they are very strong and healthy. Carlos is amazingly vigorous for a man of 70he still plays tennis twice a week with his son. A vigorous growth of ivy covered the walls.
adjective A vigorous action is done forcefully with a lot of energy. He greeted me with a vigorous shake of my hand.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vigour

form.definition: adjective If something is vile, it is very unpleasant or disgusting. The walls are painted a vile green. What on earth is that vile smell? She served us some sort of vile fish stew.

adjective In formal language, if you say something is vile, you mean that it is wicked or evil. The perpetrators of this vile crime must be brought to justice. This allegation is a vile slander on her good name.
noun A village is a small town, usually in the country.
noun A villain is someone who does criminal or evil things. He is a notorious villain and gang leader. At the end of the movie the hero shoots the villain. I'm being made out to be the villain.

noun In informal language, you can call someone a villain if they are always getting up to mischief. Raoul is a real little villainhe keeps pinching the chocolate biscuits. Some villain has left the cap off the toothpaste again.

adjective If someone is vindictive, they are spiteful and try to harm people that they think have treated them badly. Don't cross Antoinehe's a very vindictive person. It's time to forgive and forget and not be vindictive.
noun A vine is a climbing plant with a woody stem, such as the ones on which grapes grow.
noun A vine is also a creeping plant, such as the ones on which pumpkins or melons grow.
noun Vinegar is a sour liquid made from wine or cider. It is used to flavour food and is an ingredient of salad dressings and sauces.
noun A vineyard is a property or area of land where grapes are grown to make wine.
noun Wine of a particular vintage is made in a certain year or comes from a particular crop. 'What vintage is this wine?' '1993.' This bottle is a little-known South Australian vintage.

adjective If you describe something as vintage, you mean that it is a typical or very good example of its kind, dating from some time ago. Do you remember when he turned up in his pyjamas? That's vintage Desmond! They're showing a season of vintage thrillers.
adjective A vintage car is an old car of a type that isn't made any more which people buy and restore as a hobby.
noun Vinyl is a type of strong flexible plastic. It is used as a floor covering and as upholstery.

adjective If someone is violent, they are aggressive and use force to injure people or destroy things. He was abusive, and I was afraid that he might become violent. It is a very violent neighbourhood. I don't like my kids to watch such violent videos.
adjective If something such as a storm or an explosion is violent, it has great force and is very destructive. Violent waves dashed against the rock.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun violence The protest ended in rioting and violence.adverb violently He disagreed violently. The storm raged violently all night.

form.definition: noun A violin is a stringed musical instrument which you play with a bow.

noun A VIP is a celebrity or someone who is treated especially well because of their status. This word is an abbreviation of very important person. The premier and the other VIPs took their seats in the front row. As guests of the managing director, we were treated as VIPs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective VIP She was escorted into the VIP lounge. He refused to be given VIP treatment.

form.definition: noun A virgin is someone who has never had sexual intercourse.

adjective If something such as land or forest is described as virgin, it is in its original natural state. It has not been cultivated or spoilt by humans. There are 4000 acres of virgin bush in Tasmania.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun virginity She lost her virginity at the age of 16.

form.definition: adjective If a man is virile, he is physically strong and characteristically masculine in his appearance and behaviour.
noun A virtue is a good aspect of someone's character. Salim is very generousthat's just one of his many virtues.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is vice.b noun A virtue is a welcome or useful feature of something. One of the virtues of this dish is that it's quick to prepare.

form.definition: noun In formal language, virtue is the quality of being morally good. They believed that virtue would be rewarded in the afterlife.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective virtuous

form.definition: adjective If something such as a disease or poison is virulent, it is very powerful and deadly. This is a particularly virulent strain of the bacteria.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective viral ...a viral infection.

form.definition: noun A virus is an extremely small organism which causes disease. Doctors have succeeded in isolating the virus responsible for the outbreak.
noun You can say that you have a virus when you have a disease that seems to be caused by a virus. Ursula's gone to bedI hope it's just a 24-hour virus.
noun A virus is also a computer program that has been especially written to cause damage or annoyance if it is loaded onto a computer along with other programs or data.

noun A visa is a stamp or document which shows that you have official permission to visit a particular country and remain there for a certain length of time. You'll need a visa to go to New Caledonia. My visa expires at the end of the year.

adjective If something is visible, it can be seen. The boat was just visible on the horizon. The germs are not visible to the naked eye. The stain is hardly visible. There was a visible improvement in his health.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun visibility Visibility was reduced to a few metres in the fog.adverb visibly She was visibly moved by the occasion.

form.definition: noun Your vision is your ability to see. My vision has deteriorated latelyI ought to go to the optician.

noun A vision is a hallucination or an experience in which someone sees something that is not physically present. He ~saw a vision of the Virgin Mary. She had a vision of a terrible fire engulfing the house.

noun A vision is also a mental picture of how something is or might be. Jack's an idealisthe has a vision of a perfect world. I had visions of Bharati falling off her bike from the day that we gave it to her.

noun Vision is the ability to imagine clearly how things ought to be and how to bring that situation about. Governor Macquarie was a man of vision. He was concerned for the future of the colony of New South Wales.

verb If you visit a person or a place, you go to see them, usually for a fairly short time. Carmen visits her mother every Sunday. We must visit Bondi before we leave Sydney. I've never visited Europe.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun visit Lucy's here on a visit for a few days. I asked the doctor to pay a home visit.adjective visitor He rose to welcome his visitor. I can put visitors up on the sofa bed.

form.definition: adjective Visual means relating to seeing. Will you be using any visual aids during your lecture? She has a strong visual sense and finds it easy to interpret plans and diagrams.
noun A visual display unit is a computer terminal which presents information on a screen.
form.note: ... A SHORTENED FORM of this word is VDU.

form.definition: verb If you visualise something, you picture it to yourself in your mind. You imagine what it looks like or how it is. I haven't seen the house, but I can visualise it from your description. It is hard to visualise a society in which all routine work is done by robots.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this word is visualize.

form.definition: adjective If something is vital, it is necessary and extremely important. It is essential. If you want to lose weight, exercise is vital. It is vital that everyone should be aware of the emergency evacuation procedure.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb vitally Exercise is vitally important.

form.definition: noun If someone is full of vitality, they are very active and energetic. She positively glows with health and vitality.

noun Vitamins are substances found in some foods. People and animals ~need certain amounts of particular vitamins in order to remain healthy. You can also buy pills containing vitamins in case you are not getting enough in your diet. Vitamin A helps you to see in the dark.
adjective If someone is vivacious, they have a very lively personality. Michael's new girlfriend is a vivacious brunette.
adjective If something such as a colour or a design is vivid, it is very bright, bold and strong. He uses vivid blues and greens in his paintings.
adjective If something such as a description is vivid, it is clear and lively. It makes you able to imagine the thing very well. Angelo told his story in vivid detail.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb vividly

form.definition: noun The vocabulary of a language is all the words that are used in it. Is there any vocabulary in this passage that you don't know?
noun Your vocabulary is all the words that you know or use in a language. Lisa has a very wide vocabulary for her age. Reading widely will help to increase your vocabulary.
adjective Vocal means relating to the human voice. The young Italian soprano is famous for her large vocal range.
adjective If someone is vocal, they are insistent on making their views known. The debate has been dominated by a small group of vocal protestors.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See vocalist.

form.definition: noun A vocalist is a singer, especially one who performs with a band.

noun A vogue is a fashion for something such as a particular style of clothing or type of music. The present vogue is for short skirts. It's impossible to keep up with every passing vogue. Marianne is obsessed with being in vogue.
noun You use your voice to speak or sing. She's got a lovely voice. I didn't recognise his voice. He spoke in a soft voice. I heard voices in the corridor. Ann's got a coldshe's lost her voice.
noun If you have a voice in a decision, you have a say in it. Your opinion is taken into consideration. They complained that they had had no voice in the debate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb voice Lynn voiced her concern at the proposal.

form.definition: adjective In legal language, if something is void, it is not valid. It is treated as if it did not exist at all. The contract was void because it had not been properly drawn up.
noun In rather literary language, a void is an empty space. The spacecraft hurtled into the black void. Theresa felt a terrible void in her life after her husband died.

noun A volcano is a mountain formed from rock which has erupted in molten form through a crack in the earth's surface. If it is an active volcano, it is likely to erupt again and send lava, gases, steam and ash into the sky.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective volcanic

form.definition: noun A volley of shots is several of them fired at the same time or in quick succession.
noun In tennis, if you play a volley, you hit the ball back to the other player without letting it bounce first.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb volley She surprised her opponent by volleying.

form.definition: noun Volleyball is a game played between two teams. It involves hitting a large ball over a high net with your hands and not allowing it to touch the ground.
noun The volume of something is the amount of space it occupies. Volume is measured in cubic units.
noun The volume of something is the amount of it. He never expected such a large volume of work. We have received a large volume of enquiries.
noun The volume of a sound is how loud it is. I asked him to turn down the volume of his radio. You can adjust the volume with this knob, and the tuning with this one.
noun A volume is a book, especially a large one which forms part of a series. The encyclopedia consists of sixteen volumes. The price is $50 per volume, or $175 for the set of four.
adjective If something is voluntary, you do not have to do it. You can do it if you want to. Contributions are supposed to be voluntary, but many people feel pressured into paying.
adjective If you do voluntary work, you are not paid for it. You give your time to help a charity or a community organisation. Myra does a lot of voluntary work at the local hospital.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See volunteer.adverb voluntarily They handed in their guns voluntarily.

form.definition: noun A volunteer is someone who does work without receiving payment for it, especially work that is useful to society. Charities can't survive without the help of volunteers. The hospital is seeking volunteers for its medical research.
noun A volunteer is also someone who joins the armed forces because they want to and not because they are forced to do so by law.
verb If you volunteer to do something, you offer to do it without being forced to do it. Adele's always willing to helpshe volunteered to do the washing up.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective volunteer ...volunteer work.

form.definition: verb If you vomit, you throw up food from your stomach out through your mouth. I ate a bad oyster and I couldn't stop vomiting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vomit I avoided stepping in the pool of vomit.

form.definition: verb If you vote, you register your support for a particular person or plan by marking your choice on a piece of paper or by raising your hand at a meeting. In Australia all citizens must vote at elections. Who are you going to vote for? I've voted Labor all my life. The workers voted to strike. I vote we try one more time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vote Let's take a vote. Each person has one vote.noun voter

form.definition: noun A voucher is a specially printed piece of paper that is worth a certain amount of money when you use it to buy something. I received a book voucher worth $75 for my birthday. This voucher entitles you to $10 off any three-course meal. Present this voucher to receive free admission.

verb If you vow to do something, you promise to do it. You form and usually express a firm intention to do it. He vowed to be avenged. How many times has she vowed to stop drinking? I vowed never to go there again after the poor service we received.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun vow He broke his solemn vow.

form.definition: noun A vowel is a sound in a language which you make with your mouth open. A sequence of two vowels is called a diphthong.
noun A vowel is a letter of the alphabet used to represent these sounds. In English the letters a, e, i, o, u and sometimes y are vowels.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is consonant.

form.definition: noun A voyage is a long journey that you make by sea or air. Have you seen Rick's slides of his voyage to the Antarctic?
abbreviation for versus.
adjective If something is vulgar, it is crude and offensive. I don't feel comfortable with Melhe tells far too many vulgar jokes. She made a vulgar gesture when I protested.
adjective If something is vulgar, it is ostentatious and in poor taste. She wears a lot of vulgar gold jewellery.

adjective If someone is vulnerable, they are likely to suffer something unpleasant because they are in a weak position. Bullies always pick on people they see as vulnerable targets. Old people are particularly vulnerable to the cold. I don't want to make a fuss as my job is vulnerable.~[fa[xp
